This reasoning is an example of the QuantSwitch Method, which involves changing the order of quantifiers. The original premise ∀x∃yR(x, y) suggests that for every natural number, there exists another natural number that is greater (resulting in no largest natural number), but the erroneous conclusion ∃y∀xR(x, y) implies the existence of a largest natural number. This represent a switch in the order of quantifiers, which led to an invalid conclusion.

[[H]] 

Given the statement "Some students are doctors", it is possible to assert that ∃x Sx ∧ Dx, where Sx denotes that x is a student, Dx denotes that x is a doctor. The Erroneous inference "Therefore, some students are not doctors" would be ∃x Sx ∧ ¬Dx. This would fall under the type of informal fallacy known as IncorrInf, which involves making an invalid inference about propositions with existential quantifiers.

The Erroneous inference made about 'some S are P' becoming 'some S are not P' fits with the description of IncorrInf method as it fatally distorts a valid argument.

[[J/ LetClauseShift Method]]

In this scenario, the manager states "All employees will receive a bonus after completing a project," which is logically equivalent to "For all employees E, if E has completed a project (P), then E receives a bonus (B)." However, Employee A misinterprets the statement, thinking "Only when an employee receives a bonus (B) have they completed a project (P)," which is logically equivalent to "For all employees E, if E receives a bonus (B), then E has completed a project (P)." This is an example of a LetClauseShift Method, as the employee has shifted the structure of the let clause (in this case, a conditional statement) and ended up with an invalid inference.
